scenario_label: Baseline integrated management
recommendation_text: Avoid very late planting and try to synchronise planting with neighbours. Maintain recommended spacing so air can move through the canopy and leaves dry quickly. Plough under or remove heavily infected straw instead of leaving thick residues on the soil surface.

scenario_label: High humidity / frequent rain at booting–heading
recommendation_text: When blast risk is high around booting to heading under wet, cloudy conditions, consider a need-based protective fungicide spray using products recommended locally (often triazole or strobilurin-type). Aim to protect the flag leaf and emerging panicle; follow label rates and intervals strictly.

scenario_label: Lush crop with heavy nitrogen
recommendation_text: If the crop is very lush and dark green due to heavy nitrogen, skip additional top-dressings and focus on balanced N–P–K in future seasons. Split nitrogen into smaller doses and avoid one large early application that makes foliage highly blast-susceptible.
key_context_keywords: lush crop;dark green;too much nitrogen;heavy urea

scenario_label: Nursery seedlings with blast lesions
recommendation_text: Where nursery seedlings show typical blast lesions, avoid keeping the nursery waterlogged and ensure good spacing so leaves dry quickly. For the next crop, use certified seed, treat seed with an approved fungicide where recommended, and avoid sowing too densely in trays or beds.

scenario_label: Upland or AWD field under intermittent drought
recommendation_text: In upland or alternate-wetting-and-drying fields with blast and intermittent drought, avoid stressing the crop further. Maintain moderate soil moisture (do not let the soil crack severely) and apply balanced fertiliser rather than heavy nitrogen. Avoid late rescue nitrogen that triggers very lush, blast-prone regrowth.

scenario_label: Late-season neck blast near harvest
recommendation_text: If neck blast appears close to harvest, further fungicide sprays are usually of limited benefit. Focus on careful harvest and threshing to salvage as much grain as possible, and plan stronger preventive measures next season (resistant varieties, planting time, nitrogen management and timely fungicide where justified).

scenario_label: Nutrient-related brown spot in dry spells
recommendation_text: Under dry, nutrient-poor conditions with many brown spots, prioritise improving nutrition and water: apply recommended nitrogen and potassium, and resume timely irrigation if water is available. Where possible add organic matter or a silicon source to build soil health over the longer term.

scenario_label: Seedling/nursery brown spot with suspect seed
recommendation_text: If seedlings in the nursery show brown leaf blight and seed-borne brown spot is suspected, use certified seed next crop and treat seed with hot water or an approved fungicidal seed treatment according to local recommendations.

scenario_label: Severe leaf blighting in main field
recommendation_text: When brown spot is widespread with severe leaf blighting and the crop still has time to respond, a single or limited number of foliar fungicide sprays (according to local labels) can be used as support, together with correcting nutrition and water stress.

scenario_label: General field under normal moisture
recommendation_text: In normally irrigated fields with moderate brown spot, emphasise field hygiene and crop vigour: maintain good land levelling, remove volunteer rice and weeds, and avoid long periods of shallow stagnant water. Rotate with non-rice crops or fallow where possible to reduce carry-over inoculum.

scenario_label: Grain filling stage with noticeable brown spot
recommendation_text: If brown spot is visible but the crop is already at grain filling or close to maturity, additional fungicide sprays offer limited economic return. Focus on nutrition and water management to support grain filling, and plan stronger nutrient and seed management for the next season.

scenario_label: Early nursery or young crop infestation
recommendation_text: In nurseries or very young crops, clip and destroy heavily scraped or mined leaves to physically remove eggs and larvae. Avoid dense seeding and maintain weed-free bunds and field margins to reduce beetle refuges.

scenario_label: Lush nitrogen-rich crop with high adult beetle activity
recommendation_text: If the crop is very lush with high nitrogen and many hispa adults, avoid further nitrogen applications and keep water and weeds well managed. This reduces overly tender foliage and alternate hosts that favour the pest.

scenario_label: Confirmed damaging infestation over large patches
recommendation_text: When scraping damage and mines are widespread over large field patches and economic loss is likely, use a selective insecticide or neem-based product recommended locally, applied early and uniformly. Avoid repeated broad-spectrum sprays that kill natural enemies.

scenario_label: Dry spell with stressed crop
recommendation_text: During dry spells when the crop is already stressed, prioritise irrigation or moisture conservation where possible and remove heavily scraped leaves on field edges. Avoid harsh blanket insecticide sprays that may flare secondary pests when plants are weak.

scenario_label: Monitoring and IPM in low to moderate infestations
recommendation_text: When hispa scraping is present but still at low to moderate levels, regularly sample leaves to track damage and adult numbers. Conserve natural enemies by avoiding unnecessary insecticide sprays and consider botanicals (for example neem-based products) if populations begin to rise.

scenario_label: Preventive management before planting
recommendation_text: After harvest, plough in or remove stubbles and kill ratoons to destroy stem borer carry-over. Plan for synchronised planting with neighbours and avoid very late planting that exposes young crops to peak moth flights.

scenario_label: Dead hearts appearing at vegetative stage
recommendation_text: When scattered dead hearts appear, record the percentage of affected tillers or hills. If levels are below local thresholds, focus on removing heavily damaged tillers and maintaining good crop vigour rather than spraying immediately.

scenario_label: Dead hearts/whiteheads above threshold
recommendation_text: If dead hearts or whiteheads exceed local economic thresholds and cultural or biological measures are insufficient, apply a recommended stem borer insecticide (for example chlorantraniliprole-based) at the correct growth stage and water depth, following label guidance.

scenario_label: Nursery or early seedbed with high egg masses
recommendation_text: In nurseries where stem borer egg masses are frequently observed, clip seedling tips before transplanting and destroy the clippings. Avoid keeping nursery beds constantly flooded and monitor nearby lights or pheromone traps to track moth flights.

scenario_label: Late-season whiteheads near harvest
recommendation_text: If most symptoms are whiteheads appearing close to harvest, further insecticide treatment is usually not economical. Focus on harvesting in time to minimise shattering, and strengthen off-season and early-season preventive measures rather than late corrective sprays.

scenario_label: Baseline tungro prevention in endemic areas
recommendation_text: In tungro-prone zones, grow tungro-resistant or tolerant varieties and avoid highly susceptible ones. Use clean seed from healthy fields and avoid bringing seedlings from areas with known tungro outbreaks.

scenario_label: High leafhopper pressure early in season
recommendation_text: Where monitoring shows high green leafhopper populations at nursery or early tillering stages and tungro risk is known, use locally recommended insecticides targeting the vectors early in crop growth. Combine this with roguing of early yellow, stunted clumps.

scenario_label: Existing tungro patches within the field
recommendation_text: When tungro patches are already present, rogue and destroy infected hills promptly and maintain a rice-free or low-rice period between crops if possible. Focus management on preventing further spread rather than curing already infected plants.

scenario_label: Vegetative crop in tungro-prone area, few symptoms
recommendation_text: In vegetative crops in tungro-prone areas where only a few suspect plants are seen, monitor leafhopper populations and remove suspicious yellow, stunted clumps early. Avoid unnecessary insecticide sprays that may disrupt beneficial insects if vector numbers are low.

scenario_label: Planning rice-free or low-rice periods
recommendation_text: Where tungro recurs frequently, plan a rice-free or low-rice period between seasons over as wide an area as possible, combined with destruction of volunteer rice and alternate hosts on bunds and canals. This reduces both virus and vector carry-over.

scenario_label: Healthy crop – keep it that way
recommendation_text: For a healthy crop, maintain recommended varieties, certified seed, good land levelling, balanced fertilisation, timely irrigation, and regular scouting. Address small problems early so that pests and diseases do not reach damaging levels.

scenario_label: After heavy rain or flooding but no disease yet
recommendation_text: Where fields have been flooded or waterlogged but leaves are still healthy, drain excess water as soon as possible, repair bunds and channels, and avoid working in very wet fields to reduce mechanical injury. Resume normal irrigation schedules once soil structure recovers.

scenario_label: Organic or low-chemical farmer
recommendation_text: For farmers aiming to minimise chemical inputs, emphasise resistant or tolerant varieties, crop rotation where possible, regular field scouting, conservation of natural enemies, and timely cultural practices (for example weeding, residue management, water control) to keep pest and disease pressure low without routine sprays.
